author: Philip van Doorn
title: Fear and loathing are the main themes in this week’s top business stories
text:
MarketWatch rounded up the 10 most important news events of the past week. We focused on market-related issues, but we’ve included other subjects of interest to readers.
1. U.S. stocks have worst day in 18 months On Thursday, the S&P 500 SPX, -2.50% dropped 2.1%, its biggest one-day decline since February 2014 . The index was down almost as much by noon Friday. There have been many factors driving warnings about a possible end to the six-year bull market for U.S. stocks. These have included uncertainty about China’s economy and stock market, the continued weakness in the oil market, the expected increase of short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve, and a bunch of cuts to full-year sales and earnings outlooks by companies this earnings season.
Sara Sjolin shared seven charts showing the face of the market panic .

2. China’s crumbling stocks The Shanghai Composite Index fell 8% from a week earlier through Thursday. The index is up 64%, but that is of little comfort to investors who came late to the party. The index is down 29% from its high June 12.
Chao Deng discussed the Chinese government’s actions to calm the nation’s stock market.
Mark Hulbert said the bear market in China doesn’t necessarily signal a bear market for U.S. stocks .
Irwin Kellner talked about China’s currency devaluation .
3. What’s next for the markets? It turned out that Tom McClellan’s timing was right on the money when he said earlier in the week that stocks could begin falling on Thursday .
Victor Reklaitis rounded up analysts’ sentiment following Thursday’s market decline.
Jeff Reeves warned investors to prepare for a correction in stocks , saying Thursday’s decline was “a long time coming.”
4. Contrary opinions Despite all the dire warnings, there are still plenty of analysts who believe in the bull market.
Michael Brush said the extreme level of negative sentiment argues for a rebound in share prices .
